bibl.title: Letter from Laura Reed Blincoe to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 14, 1903

div1.p: Blincoe provides recollections of Walter Reed as a youth. She gives the family genealogy and a description of the house in Gloucester County, Virginia, where Reed was born.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Reed Blincoe to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 14, 1903
div1.p:
No one regrets half
as much as I do, my tardiness in an-
swering your kind letter of inquiry in
regards to facts of Walter's birth. Nothing
but the pressure of heavy domestic cares
has prevented, for I assure you I appre-
ciate to the fullest, your interest as well
as the citizens of Gloucester, in preserving
all matters of fact in regard to my
dear brother. My mother's maiden name
was Phaeaba White, She was the daughter
of Stephen & Christian White & was born
June 14, 1816, in the County of Pasquo-
tank, N.C.- She was thirty-five years
& three months old when Walter was
born & he was the last of her children --
the youngest -- I mean. Dr: William
Waller was her physician- He was a
near neighbor & great friend of the family --
was a young married man & may be
living now for aught I know. I was a
child of eleven years & well remember
the house -- an old fashioned framed
country house -- built in “old timey” style.
2
It was a small affair -- with one large
room & a smaller “shed” room back --
one large room up stairs & a porch
in front- It was in a very small village
called “Belle Roy” -- but I hardly think
there were enough houses to justify the
name even of a village. I could go to
the house & place my hands on it if
I only had some sort of sufficient loco-
motion! We lived there the first year of my
father's appointment to Gloucester Circuit-
The next year he had built, with the
aid of his brethren of the circuit, just
across the road & not far from the house
in which Walter was born, a much
nicer & more convenient home for the
preacher. I suppose that house may
be still standing- When Walter was a
month old, (you know Gloucester is the
place for oysters & we enjoyed them very
often) my father so proud & fond of him
& wishing to christen initiate him (I suppose) or
to introduce him to the best the country,
very “sillily” (my word) gave him a small
oyster!- Then Dr: Waller was called in
a hurry for our baby got very sick!-
When he was four months old he con-
tracted whooping cough & that came
3
near putting an end to his dear little life.
But he outweathered the gale -- thanks to a
kind Providence & the care of a good physician
& the most devoted mother that ever lived!
Another fright we had about his babyship
was coming in contact with a very virulent
form of scarlet-fever when he was six months
old. We were visiting & one of the six children
of the family broke out (without any warning)
with the fever. I had slept with the child
just as she broke out with it- Of course we
left the place & were careful not to come in
contact with others. Before the end of the
week, two of the six children of our friend,
had died with the fever. But we never
contracted it at all. I will say here
that I think the village or post-office of
“Belle Roy”, was about six miles from
the Court House. There were four other
children. Beginning with myself --
the oldest -- Laura, James Clayton,-
Thomas Walk, Christopher -- & Walter,
I think that you might get some facts
from my brother J. C. Reed, His
address is 518 Clay Street, Lynchburg, Va-
if you have time to write to him -- I
being the oldest child & only daughter
was sent away to school very early & hence
4
after I was fourteen years old, I saw the
dear little boy only in vacations- Then being
married when he was about ten years old
took me away from home again. That's why
I think that my brother could give you a
more interesting letter than myself- I see that
I have forgotten to give you the date of my
mother's death. She died in Charlottesville
Feb; 5. 1866. -- aged, 49 years, 5 months & 19 days.
I have “jumbled” up things very much Dr:
Kean but if you could know under what
disabilities I write, you would readily
excuse an old woman. As to the coat of
arms -- I had it once -- found it in a
very valuable work on English & Scotch
names owned by Dr: W. H. H. Shackston
of Farmville, While there visiting my
father in 1897- I was much interested
in looking our names & copied our coat of
arms for fun- Think I sent it to one of
my brothers- I will try my best to get it for
you if the book can be found- But Dr: Shackston
has died since & I hear that his library was
destroyed- Will do my best & write to-night
for the information you wish. Hoping I haven't
wearied you & wishing you would write again
& assuring you there's nothing dearer to me than
C1
B3
the life & memory of my darling brother
I remain
